methods 3/4 a summary of vce methods 3/4 by briano
1 polynomial functions 1.1 what is it 1.2 remainder theorem 1.3 factor theorem 1.4 quadratic formula 1.5 difference and sum of two cubes

1 polynomial functions 1.1 what is it a polynomial can have constants, variables and exponents, but never division by a variable. exponents of variables in polynomial are 0, 1, 2,.. (zero or positive integer number) \[P(x)=a_nx^n+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+...+a_1x+a_0\] 1.1.1 degree the degree of the polynomial is the largest exponent of that variable. degree name rule 0 constant \(a\) 1 linear \(ax+b\) 2 quadratic \(ax^2+bx+c\) 3 qubic \(ax^3+bx^2+cx+d\) 4 quartic \(ax^4+bx^3+cx^2+dx+e\) 1.1.2 general form \[f(x)=ax^3+bx^2+cx+d\] easy to find y-intercept hard to graph 1.1.3 turning point form \[f(x)=a(x-b)(x-c)(x-d)\] easy to find x-intercepts easy to graph 1.2 remainder theorem if \(P(x)\) is divided by \((ax+b)\) the remainder is \(P(-\frac{b}{a})\) 1.3 factor theorem if \(P(-\frac{b}{a})=0\) then \((ax+b)\) is a factor 1.4 quadratic formula \(f(x)=ax^2+bx+c\) if \(f(x)=0\) then \(x=\frac{-b\pm{}\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\) the discriminant: \(\Delta=b^2-4ac\) if \(\Delta>0\) then the quadratic has 2 real solutions if \(\Delta=0\) then the quadratic has 1 real solution if \(\Delta<{}0\) then the quadratic has no real solutions the vertex is at \((-\frac{b}{2a},f(-\frac{b}{2a}))\) 1.5 difference and sum of two cubes \(x^3-a^3=(x-a)(x^2+ax+a^2)\) \(x^3+a^3=(x+a)(x^2-ax+a^2)\)
2 more functions 2.1 power functions 2.2 exponentials and logarithms 2.3 circular functions

2 more functions 2.1 power functions 2.2 exponentials and logarithms 2.2.1 exponential functions for \(a\in{}R^+\setminus\{1\}\), the graph \(y=a^x\) has the following properties: the y-axis intercept is 1 the x-axis is an asymptote index laws \(x^a\times{}x^b=x^{a+b}\) \(x^a\div{}x^b=x^{a-b}\) \((xy)^a=x^ay^a\) \((\frac{x}{y})^a=\frac{x^a}{y^a}\) \((x^a)^b=x^{ab}\) \(x^0=1\) 2.2.2 logarithmic functions for \(a\in{}R^+\setminus\{1\}\), the graph \(y=\log_ax\) has the following properties: the x-axis intercept is 1 the y-axis is an asymptote log laws \(\log_am+\log_an=\log_a(mn)\) \(\log_am-\log_an=\log_a(\frac{m}{n})\) \(p\log_am=\log_a(m^p)\) \(-\log_am=\log_a(\frac{1}{m})\) \(\log_a1=0\) \(\log_aa=1\) \(\log_am=\frac{\log_em}{\log_ea}=\frac{\log_{10}m}{\log_{10}a}\) 2.2.3 exponential growth and decay model for quantity growing/decaying at an exponential rate: \(A=A_0b^t\) \(A_0\) is the initial quantity \(b=e^k\) is the rate constant (growth if \(b>1\), decay if \(b<1\)) \(t\) is time cell growth - doubles every \(T_D\) (unit of time): \(N=N_02^{\frac{t}{T_D}}\) \(N_0\) is the initial quantity \(T_D\) is the generation time (how long it takes to double) \(t\) is time 2.3 circular functions
3 advance functions 3.1 hybrid functions 3.2 inverse functions 3.3 composite functions

4 transformations 4.1 translations 4.2 dilations 4.3 transformation formula 4.4 combinations of transformations

4 transformations 4.1 translations the graph is moved (translated) but the shape stays the same 4.2 dilations the graph is stretch or squashed, if the factor is negative the graph is reflected over the axis 4.3 transformation formula \[\begin{bmatrix}x'\\y'\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}a&0\\0&b\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x\\y\end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}h\\k\end{bmatrix}\] \[x'=ax+h\qquad y'=by+k\] \[x=\frac{x'-h}{a}\qquad y=\frac{y'-k}{b}\] \[y=f(x)\] \[\frac{y-k}{b}=f(\frac{x-h}{a})\] \[y=bf(\frac{x-h}{a})+k\] dilation of factor \(a\) from the \(y\) axis dilation of factor \(b\) from the \(x\) axis translation of \(h\) units in the positive \(x\) direction translation of \(k\) units in the positive \(y\) direction 4.4 combinations of transformations using translation and dilation together. order matters!
5 calculus 5.1 continuity and differentiability 5.2 differentiation 5.3 antidifferentiation

5 calculus 5.1 continuity and differentiability \(f(x)\) is continous at \(x=a\) where \(f(a)\) is defined \(\lim_{x\to{}a}f(x)=f(a)\) a function is differentiable if it is continuous and its derivative is also continuous at all values of \(x\) 5.2 differentiation if \(f'(x)\) is the derivative function of a function \(f(x)\) then \(f'(a)\) returns the gradient of the function \(f(x)\) at \(x=a\) \[f'(x)=\lim_{h\to{}0}\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}\] 5.2.1 common derivative \(f(x)\) \(f'(x)\) \(x^n\) \(nx^{n-1}\) \((ax+b)^n\) \(an(ax+b)^{n-1}\) \(e^{f(x)}\) \(f'(x)e^{f(x)}\) \(\log_ef(x)\) \(\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)}\) \(\sin{f(x)}\) \(f'(x)\cos{f(x)}\) \(\cos{f(x)}\) \(-f'(x)\sin{f(x)}\) \(\tan{f(x)}\) \(f'(x)\sec^2{f(x)}\) 5.2.2 chain rule \[\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{dy}{du}\frac{du}{dx}\] 5.2.3 product rule \[\frac{d}{dx}uv=v\frac{du}{dx}+u\frac{dv}{dx}\] 5.2.4 quotient rule \[\frac{d}{dx}uv=\frac{v\frac{du}{dx}-u\frac{dv}{dx}}{v^2}\] 5.3 antidifferentiation
